rename.to: "mock-maker-inline" prevents collection of code coverage for spys

body: @Godin Your initial description is about code coverage in general, but this issue only affects mocks created with `@Spy` or `Mockito.spy` right?

On a different note: my expectation for the code coverage would be that `getName` does not have any coverage, since that method is mocked. So that means that nor the default mock maker nor the inline mock maker generate the correct coverage imo

@TimvdLippe 

> Your initial description is about code coverage in general, but this issue only affects mocks created with @Spy or Mockito.spy right?

Yes, given example is only about `Mockito.spy`. I do not expect to have coverage in case of complete mocks ðŸ˜‰ 

> On a different note: my expectation for the code coverage would be that getName does not have any coverage, since that method is mocked. So that means that nor the default mock maker nor the inline mock maker generate the correct coverage imo

Right. Expectation is to have coverage only for non-mocked method (`sayHello`). I didn't noticed this before, being more focused on obvious difference between default mock maker and inline. Do you think that this case might be different in Mockito 1.x? I'll check.

@TimvdLippe hm, on given example **Mockito 1.9.5** and **1.10.19** fails even without coverage:

```
java.lang.ExceptionInInitializerError
    at org.mockito.internal.exceptions.stacktrace.ConditionalStackTraceFilter.<init>(ConditionalStackTraceFilter.java:17)
    at org.mockito.exceptions.base.MockitoException.filterStackTrace(MockitoException.java:30)
    at org.mockito.exceptions.base.MockitoException.<init>(MockitoException.java:19)
    at org.mockito.exceptions.misusing.MockitoConfigurationException.<init>(MockitoConfigurationException.java:18)
    at org.mockito.internal.configuration.ClassPathLoader.loadImplementations(ClassPathLoader.java:145)
    at org.mockito.internal.configuration.ClassPathLoader.findPluginImplementation(ClassPathLoader.java:110)
    at org.mockito.internal.configuration.ClassPathLoader.findPlatformMockMaker(ClassPathLoader.java:106)
    at org.mockito.internal.configuration.ClassPathLoader.<clinit>(ClassPathLoader.java:59)
    at org.mockito.internal.util.MockUtil.<clinit>(MockUtil.java:21)
    at org.mockito.internal.MockitoCore.<init>(MockitoCore.java:40)
    at org.mockito.Mockito.<clinit>(Mockito.java:932)
    at ExampleTest.test(ExampleTest.java:7)
    ...
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
    at org.mockito.internal.exceptions.stacktrace.StackTraceFilter.<clinit>(StackTraceFilter.java:21)
    ... 41 more
```
@Godin did you clean the directory and recompile? Sometimes lingering class files cause these problems.

@TimvdLippe I almost always do `mvn clean verify`. But double checked and failure was in presence of `src/test/resources/mockito-extensions/org.mockito.plugins.MockMaker`. No failure after removal and result remains the same as for 2.2.x - both methods marked as covered.
@TimvdLippe Ouch, my bad - I'm probably setup spy incorrectly, sorry, I'll recheck everything.

issue.title: Coverage of runtime modified classes

milestone.title: Priority: cool but low priority
milestone.description: Cool feature or important bug that needs to be implemented or fixed. But given the limited resources we can't pickup work right now.

issue.body:
_Mocking framework use case_
It is common for a mocking framework (such as PowerMock/EasyMock) to modify a class under test to intercept code, such as a static class method being called to a stub/mock. This changes the CRC hash of the class bytes, hence the Analyzer (in reporting) can not match the code executed with the original class code. The report will then show no coverage for the class under test.

Is it possible to enhance the Analyzer to merge the coverage data from the modified class into a record for the original class? I'm thinking of an option in a report to use an alternate ExecutionDataStore that permits this type of merging.

I understand that instruction/statement level coverage data might be incorrect / unaligned, however we'd see great value in class and method level coverage reporting.
